title: JAFF Market 2025 Opens With Indonesian Cultural Leaders Framing National Film Ecosystem and International Visibility
description: The second edition of the JAFF Market opened in Yogyakarta with a traditional Hanoman dance performance before market director Linda Gozali â€“ who is
body:
The second edition of the JAFF Market opened in Yogyakarta with a traditional Hanoman dance performance before market director Linda Gozali â€“ who is also a producer with Magma Entertainment â€“ formally began the program, setting the tone for a year she described as a strategic phase in the platformâ€™s development.

	â€œItâ€™s a baby â€” JAFF is 20 years old, and our market is only in its second edition,â€ Gozali said, referring to the Jogja-Netpac Asian Film Festival, the long-running Yogyakarta festival whose industry platform is the JAFF Market. â€œBut we believe it is a reliable and structured, future-oriented industry platform.â€ She announced a major increase in participation: â€œThis year we have 116 exhibitors, 122 companies, and more than 1,400 accreditation badgesâ€¦ Last year it was only about 900 to 1,000.â€ Encouraging attendees to move through the expanded venue, she said, â€œOne thing I would like to remind everybody â€” you have to walk to every single corner of this venue. You cannot miss even a single thing.â€
	

	Gozali positioned the JAFF Market as a regional and global connector. â€œJAFF Market exists as a strategic bridge connecting projects, talents, companies and investors from Indonesia to the regional and even global industry,â€ she said. â€œIdeas find direction, strategies find momentum, creative ambition meets real pathways in production, distribution and even beyond.â€ The festival, now in its 20th year, presents its top honor, the Golden Hanoman Award, to the best Asian feature in competition.


	Gozali then introduced Ahmad Mahendra, Director General of Cultural Development, Utilization and Fostering at the Ministry of Culture of the Republic of Indonesia, who delivered greetings from the Minister of Culture. Mahendra noted that JAFF Market provides essential visibility: â€œJAFF Market is more of a transactional or pitching forum. This is where the ecosystem finds room to meet,â€ he said, calling it â€œthe only showcase we have to be more visible internationally.â€
	

	Mahendra detailed the ministryâ€™s initiatives over the past year: â€œWe have facilitated 85 filmmakers to six international festivalsâ€¦ 13 film festivals within Indonesiaâ€¦ 27 Indonesian films entering nominations at international festivalsâ€¦ five films receiving international recognition.â€ He added that four Indonesian filmmakers served as jurors at major global events and highlighted talent development efforts: â€œMore than 1,200 talents have been producedâ€¦ 18 of them have received international recognition in Busan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Berlin and Rotterdam.â€

	He praised Yogyakartaâ€™s cultural ecosystem and said, â€œIndonesia owes JAFF and JAFF Market. This is our showcase to be more visible internationally.â€

	Sultan Baktiar Najamudin, Chair of the Regional Representative Council of the Republic of Indonesia, followed with remarks framing JAFF Market within the cultural and economic fabric of Indonesia. He opened by acknowledging the recent disasters in Sumatra: â€œThe voice of nature has become louder than humansâ€¦ This is an ecological alarm for all of us.â€

	He described JAFF Market as â€œa reflection of the long journey of Indonesiaâ€™s film ecosystem,â€ saying, â€œIdeas meet craft, craft becomes opportunity, and opportunity creates hope.â€ Najamudin emphasized the industryâ€™s economic impact: â€œIf the national film industry grows, regional economies will also advance.â€

	Calling Indonesia â€œthe greatest cinematic stage God has given us,â€ he invoked landscapes â€œfrom Sabang to Meraukeâ€¦ from the beaches of Mentawai to the jungles of Sumatra.â€ Addressing young filmmakers directly, he said, â€œThe world is waiting.â€

	JAFF Market 2025 is held in Yogyakarta from Nov. 29 to Dec. 1.

schema.headline: JAFF Market 2025 Opens With Indonesian Cultural Leaders Framing National Film Ecosystem and International Visibility

title: Majid Majidiâ€™s â€˜Children of Heavenâ€™ Remake Among MD Picturesâ€™ JAFF Market Slate
description: Indonesian production powerhouse MD Pictures is betting big on remakes and franchise fare for 2026, unveiling a slate anchored by an adaptation of M
body:
Indonesian production powerhouse MD Pictures is betting big on remakes and franchise fare for 2026, unveiling a slate anchored by an adaptation of Majid Majidiâ€™s Oscar-nominated Iranian drama â€œChildren of Heavenâ€ and the final chapter of its popular â€œDanurâ€ horror franchise at the JAFF Market. 

	Director Hanung Bramantyo is helming the â€œChildren of Heavenâ€ remake, with young actors Jared Ali and Humaira Jahra playing the siblings Ali and Zahra. Bramantyo led a talk at the MD booth titled â€œChildren of Heaven: The Art of Film Adaptation.â€
	

	The company also presented â€œDanur the Last Chapter,â€ directed by Awi Suryadi, as the concluding installment of the â€œDanurâ€ franchise. Cast member Zee Asadel participated in a meet-and-greet with festival attendees.


	MD Picturesâ€™ 2026 lineup includes a Korean horror remake, adapting â€œGonjiam: Haunted Asylumâ€ (2018) as â€œRumah Sakit Angker Korea,â€ directed by Anggy Umbara. The cast features Arbani Yasiz, Elang El Gibran, Saputra Kori and YouTuber Jang Hansol.

	Director Kimo Stamboel, who led a creative talk about â€œJanur Ireng: Sewu Dino the Sequelâ€ (releasing Dec. 24) with cast member Gisellma, will return to helm â€œIvanna 2,â€ another entry in the â€œDanur Universeâ€ franchise.

	â€œOur ambition doesnâ€™t stop here â€“ MD can expand internationally even further, proving we are the biggest content powerhouse in Southeast Asia,â€ said Manoj Punjabi, CEO and founder of MD Entertainment. â€œWhatever good films exist, we will fight for them.â€

	The company also hosted a panel titled â€œSet, Space, Story: When Space Tells a Story with TACO,â€ featuring TACO Group, an Indonesian supplier of interior-exterior materials for film production. MD Entertainment opened collaboration opportunities for creative projects at the market.
	

	MD Pictures released â€œKKN di Desa Penariâ€ in 2022, which became Indonesiaâ€˜s highest-grossing horror film with over 10 million admissions. The company acquired and launched streaming platform MDTV in early 2025.

	The second edition of JAFF Market runs Nov. 29-Dec. 1 at Jogja Expo Center in Yogyakarta.

schema.headline: Majid Majidiâ€™s â€˜Children of Heavenâ€™ Remake Among MD Picturesâ€™ JAFF Market Slate

title: Jenna Ortega Says Itâ€™s â€˜Very Easy to Be Terrifiedâ€™ of AI: â€˜It Feels Like Weâ€™ve Opened Pandoraâ€™s Box,â€™ but â€˜Thereâ€™s Certain Things Itâ€™s Just Not Able to Replicateâ€™
description: Jenna Ortega sounded off on artificial intelligence at the Marrakech Film Festival, saying â€œitâ€™s very easy to be terrifiedâ€ of the â€œdeep uncertainty
body:
Jenna Ortega sounded off on artificial intelligence at the Marrakech Film Festival, saying â€œitâ€™s very easy to be terrifiedâ€ of the â€œdeep uncertaintyâ€ it brings to filmmaking and the world.

	The â€œWednesdayâ€ star is serving on the jury at the Moroccan fest, which is being headed by â€œParasiteâ€ filmmaker Bong Joon Ho. Asked about the proliferation of AI in cinema at the jury press conference on Saturday morning, both Ortega and Bong made their opinions clear.
	

	Ortega said that looking back at the history of humankind, â€œwe just always take things too far and I think itâ€™s very easy to be terrified â€” I know I am â€” of deep uncertainty.â€ She added that, with AI, â€œit kind of feels like weâ€™ve opened Pandoraâ€™s box in a way.â€


	However, Ortega is hopeful that the growth of AI could lead to a new artistic revolution. â€œIn these difficult and confusing times, oftentimes it pushes the artist to speak out more, to do more, for there to be this new awakening and passion and protection and I want to assume and hope that thatâ€™s the case,â€ she said. â€œBut thereâ€™s certain things that AI just isnâ€™t able to replicate. Thereâ€™s beauty in difficulty and thereâ€™s beauty in mistakes, and a computer canâ€™t do that. A computer has no soul.â€

	Ortega said that she hopes AI â€œcomes to a point where it becomes sort of mental junk food and we feel sick and we donâ€™t know why. I think, as terrible as it is to say, sometimes audiences need to be deprived of something in order to appreciate something again.â€

	Bong agreed with Ortega, saying AI could be â€œgoodâ€ in the sense that â€œitâ€™s the very beginning of the human race finally seriously thinking about what only humans can do.â€ But, he added with a laugh: â€œMy personal answer is Iâ€™m going to organize a military squad where their mission is to destroy AI all over the world.â€
	

	Alongside Ortega and Bong, the Marrakech jury includes â€œFuriosaâ€ lead Anya Taylor-Joy, â€œPast Livesâ€ and â€œMaterialistsâ€ filmmaker Celine Song, â€œTitaneâ€ Palme dâ€™Or winner Julia Ducournau, Bralizian director Karim AÃ¯nouz, Moroccan filmmaker Hakim Belabbes and Iranian-American actor-director Payman Maadi.

	Song also didnâ€™t mince her words on the topic of AI, saying: â€œTo quote Guillermo del Toro, whoâ€™s going to be here at this festival soon, fuck AI.â€ She added that it is â€œcompletely destroying our planetâ€ and â€œcolonizing our mind and the way that we encounter images, the way we encounter sound.â€

	â€œIâ€™m very concerned about it because I think that the No. 1 thing that weâ€™re here to defend as artists is humanity,â€ Song continued. â€œItâ€™s trying to encroach on what makes our lives very beautiful and very hard and what makes life worth doing â€¦ Deeply and not very respectfully, fuck AI.â€

	Elsewhere during the conference, Taylor-Joy was asked her thoughts on being part of a jury where she will be judging other actorsâ€™ performances. She offered a poignant response: â€œWe live in a world where thereâ€™s a lot of premium placed on how loud you can be. If you can out scream somebody else, what your argument is, youâ€™re taught to have an opinion more than youâ€™re taught to have critical thinking. I believe that in silence, even if it is uncomfortable at the beginning, it just teaches you to be a much better listener. I think in general, not only in art but where weâ€™re at in the world currently, I think weâ€™d all be a lot better off if we listened more than we yelled on top of each other.â€

	Marrakech Film Festival, which runs through Dec. 6, officially kicked off on Friday night with a screening of Gus Van Santâ€™s â€œDead Manâ€™s Wire.â€ Its lineup also includes tributes to Jodie Foster and del Toro alongside screenings of â€œA Private Lifeâ€ and â€œFrankensteinâ€, as well as conversations with Kleber MendonÃ§a Filho, Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences CEO Bill Kramer, â€œThe Matrixâ€ star Laurence Fishburne, â€œIt Was Just an Accidentâ€ Palme dâ€™Or winner Jafar Panahi and â€œBlondeâ€ director Andrew Dominik.

	Marrakechâ€™s official competition comprises 14 features made by first- or second-time filmmakers from around the world in an effort to discover new international talent. Other films playing during the festival include Chloe Zhaoâ€™s â€œHamnet,â€ Maryam Touzaniâ€™s â€œCalle MÃ¡lagaâ€ and closer â€œPalestine 36.â€

schema.headline: Jenna Ortega Says Itâ€™s â€˜Very Easy to Be Terrifiedâ€™ of AI: â€˜It Feels Like Weâ€™ve Opened Pandoraâ€™s Box,â€™ but â€˜Thereâ€™s Certain Things Itâ€™s Just Not Able to Replicateâ€™

title: Indonesiaâ€™s Mandela Pictures Unveils Three-Film Slate, Launches Horror-Focused Genre Studio BN13 (EXCLUSIVE)
description: Indonesian production company Mandela Pictures has revealed a new film slate and launched BN13, a genre studio dedicated to developing horror and ge
body:
Indonesian production company Mandela Pictures has revealed a new film slate and launched BN13, a genre studio dedicated to developing horror and genre content rooted in Indonesian folklore and mythology.

	The Jakarta-based company revealed three feature projects set for release over the next two years: â€œBisikan Desa Gringsing â€” Whisper of Fatimah,â€ â€œRumah Singgahâ€ and â€œLukisan Berlumur Darah.â€


	â€œBisikan Desa Gringsing â€” Whisper of Fatimahâ€ represents a significant milestone as the first Indonesia-Singapore-Malaysia horror co-production and the first regional horror film to utilize virtual production technology. The project, produced by Mandela Pictures and OMG Studios Singapore, is written and directed by Ivander Tedjasukmana and is currently wrapping principal photography. Aghniny Haque leads the cast, joined by Surya Saputra, Kiki Narendra, Khiva Iskak and Fatmah Nahdi. Production took place at OMG Studiosâ€™ virtual production facility in Johor Bahru, Malaysia, and on location in Subang, West Java.
	

	â€œRumah Singgahâ€ is an emotional drama centered on cancer patients pursuing their bucket list goals. The co-production between Mandela Pictures, Senara and Limelight Pictures is directed by Dyan Sunu Prastowo from a screenplay by Raditya, based on a story by Celvin Jaya Hadi. Zara Adhisty and Devano Danendra star alongside Ciccio Manassero, Messi Gusti, Dewi Irawan and Aming.

	â€œLukisan Berlumur Darahâ€ will remake the 1988 Indonesian horror cult classic. The co-production between Mandela Pictures and Relate Films will be written and directed by Adriyanto Dewo, with production scheduled to begin in the second quarter of 2026.
	

	The newly established BN13 studio will focus on developing intellectual property grounded in cultural research and local folklore, with plans to produce two to three horror and genre projects annually. The studioâ€™s initial slate includes â€œIstana Ratu Kidul,â€ â€œTeror Gaib Satu Malamâ€ and â€œWarisan Ilmu Hitam.â€

	â€œIstana Ratu Kidulâ€ is being developed as a cross-format property exploring the relationship between humans and the Queen of the Southern Sea, blending Javanese mythology with contemporary storytelling.

	â€œWith this new slate and the launch of BN13, we want to show how Mandela Pictures continues to drive collaboration, adopt new technologies, and craft stories that not only entertain but also leave a strong emotional imprint on audiences,â€ said Manoj Samtani, CEO of Mandela Pictures.

	BN13 is being developed in collaboration with Dienan Silmy and Sonya Laoh, with projects designed for multiple formats including features, series, documentaries and digital content.â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹

schema.headline: Indonesiaâ€™s Mandela Pictures Unveils Three-Film Slate, Launches Horror-Focused Genre Studio BN13 (EXCLUSIVE)

title: Vincent Lindon Bets on Socially Conscious Films That â€˜Prevent Him From Behaving Badlyâ€™: â€˜Iâ€™m Weak. They Force Me to Be Strongerâ€™
description:
French actor Vincent Lindon often plays well-meaning characters. But he canâ€™t take credit for their selfless choices, he stressed.

	â€œWhen I made â€˜W
body:
French actor Vincent Lindon often plays well-meaning characters. But he canâ€™t take credit for their selfless choices, he stressed.

	â€œWhen I made â€˜Welcomeâ€™ [about a man helping Kurdish refugee] there were people in the street who shook my hand and said: â€˜Thank you very much for what you do for the migrants. Really, Mr. Lindon, bravo.â€™ I replied: â€˜Thank you, but itâ€™s not meâ€™.â€Â 


	â€œWhen I made â€˜The Measure of a Man,â€™ they said: â€˜Youâ€™re really brave.â€™ They confuse what I do in films with who I am in real life. But my small contribution is that Iâ€™m still making them. I couldâ€™ve been making bigger films, earning more money and taking fewer risks.â€
	

	Speaking at Torino Film Festival, where heâ€™s set to pick up the Stella della Mole award during the closing ceremony, Lindon opened up about what drives most of his choices.Â 

	â€œIf a film Iâ€™m in can change even one person, if it can change the opinion of someone whoâ€™s racist, anti-Semitic or homophobic, then itâ€™s good that Iâ€™m doing this job.â€

	He said that some of his roles have â€œprevented him from behaving badly in life.â€

	â€œI canâ€™t speak badly to those who serve me in restaurants. I canâ€™t go on holiday to Saint-Tropez or drive a convertible. I have to behave like my characters, because thereâ€™s nothing worse than making people believe in something yet being the opposite in real life.â€Â 

	He added: â€œFamous people like to preach, yet they still use their private jets and eat in palaces. Thatâ€™s fine, everyone has their own conscience, but then donâ€™t talk to me about carbon dioxide pollution.â€
	

	â€œIâ€™m a human being: I am weak. These films force me to be stronger, if only a little.â€Â 

	At the fest, Lindon presented StÃ©phane BrizÃ©â€™s â€œAt War,â€ about a factory strike: â€œItâ€™s one of my favorite films, and I shot it with my favorite director.â€ Theyâ€™ve also made â€œThe Measure of a Man,â€ which won him a CÃ©sar and an award at Cannes, â€œMademoiselle Chambon,â€ â€œA Few Hours of Springâ€ and â€œAnother World.â€

	He also introduced the audience to Jean Boronat, one of the non-professional actors from the set, who praised Lindon for â€œbeing modest yet doing a lot for people outside of films.â€ â€œIâ€™m in love with what he represents and embodies.â€Â 

	Lindonâ€™s no stranger to showier roles, having appeared in the controversial Cannes winner â€œTitaneâ€ and played sculptor Auguste Rodin. He has also recently joined the star-studded cast of Ruben Ã–stlundâ€™s â€œThe Entertainment System Is Down.â€ However, it was â€œAt Warâ€ that â€œtouched him especially deeply.â€Â 

	â€œMy character is a trade unionist, but heâ€™s ready to lose his life, lose his job, lose his family. Heâ€™s ready to lose everything to help a cause move forward,â€ he explained.Â Â 

	â€œWe often say â€˜Iâ€™d give anything for things to go better,â€™ but we donâ€™t really mean it. We would give a lot, but not everything. Him, he keeps nothing for himself.â€Â 

	The role was one of his biggest challenges heâ€™d ever faced as an actor.Â Â 

	â€œI needed to prove to myself that, despite coming from a bourgeois family, I could still embody him. I had to let go of many things and privileges. I know what it cost me, but I donâ€™t regret it. In fact, it brought me a lot.â€

schema.headline: Vincent Lindon Bets on Socially Conscious Films That â€˜Prevent Him From Behaving Badlyâ€™: â€˜Iâ€™m Weak. They Force Me to Be Strongerâ€™

title: Kamila Andiniâ€™s â€˜Four Seasons in Javaâ€™ Lands International Production Alliance for Forka Films
description: Indonesian production company Forka Films has unveiled a production consortium for auteur Kamila Andiniâ€™s upcoming feature â€œFour Seasons in Java,â€ s
body:
Indonesian production company Forka Films has unveiled a production consortium for auteur Kamila Andiniâ€™s upcoming feature â€œFour Seasons in Java,â€ scheduled for 2026 release.

	The announcement came at the JAFF Market 2025 in Yogyakarta. The cast includes Putri Marino, Arya Saloka, Christine Hakim and Hana Pitrashata Malasan. The on-stage event also showcased some first-look footage from the film. 


	The project won two prizes at the inaugural Tokyo Gap-Financing Market Awards in October, securing the Tokyo Projects Award worth $13,225 and the Kongchak Award from Cambodia-based Kongchak Studio, offering sound post-production services valued at $25,000. The film previously participated in the Venice Gap-Financing Market.
	

	The Indonesian consortium brings together Miles Films, Imajinari, Jagartha, Trinity, Team Up, Julie Estelle and Navvaros. Oriflame has joined as brand sponsor, with Jaris & K serving as out-of-home media partner.

	The projectâ€™s international co-production partners span eight territories: Storm Films (Norway), Lemming Films (Netherlands), One Two Films (Germany), Ici Et La Production (France), Giraffe Pictures (Singapore), PFX (Poland), Brand Film (Indonesia) and Chada Entertainment (Thailand).

	Development backing comes from Hubert Bals Fund Development, Hubert Bals Fund + Netherlands Film Fund, and Sorfond â€“ The Norwegian South Film Fund.

	The magical realist drama follows Pertiwi, a woman who returns to her village after more than a decade in prison for killing a young man while defending herself from attempted rape. Her homecoming coincides with the arrival of electricity to the remote community.
	

	Formerly known as Fourcolours Films, Forka Films was founded in 2001 and is led by filmmaker Ifa Isfansyah, who also serves as director of the Jogja-Netpac Asian Film Festival. The companyâ€™s credits include Eddie Cahyonoâ€™s â€œSitiâ€ (Telluride 2015), Kamila Andiniâ€™s â€œYuniâ€ (Platform Prize, Toronto 2021) and Andiniâ€™s â€œBefore, Now & Thenâ€ (Silver Bear, Berlinale 2022). Garin Nugrohoâ€™s â€œMemories of My Bodyâ€ premiered in Veniceâ€™s Horizons strand ib 2018, while Wicaksono Wisnu Legowoâ€™s â€œTurahâ€ served as Indonesiaâ€™s submission to the Oscars in 2018.

	Most recently, the company produced Netflix miniseries â€œCigarette Girl,â€ directed by Isfansyah and Andini, which won best mini-series at the 2024 Seoul International Drama Awards.

schema.headline: Kamila Andiniâ€™s â€˜Four Seasons in Javaâ€™ Lands International Production Alliance for Forka Films

title: France Deepens Indonesian Cinema Partnership Through Expanded Film Lab, Festival Initiatives: â€˜A Lot of Stories to Tellâ€™ (EXCLUSIVE)
description: France and Indonesia are strengthening their strategic cultural partnership through an expanded suite of cinema initiatives, as the France-Indonesia
body:
France and Indonesia are strengthening their strategic cultural partnership through an expanded suite of cinema initiatives, as the France-Indonesia Film Lab returns for its second edition at JAFF Market.

	Indonesia is a key priority for the French government, and culture is at the heart of the strategic partnership, according to Fabien Penone, French ambassador to Indonesia, Timor Leste and ASEAN. The partnership recognizes that both countries have important and dynamic cultural industries covering different sectors, especially cinema, he says.
	

	The collaboration builds on high-level governmental commitments, including state visits by Presidents Emmanuel Macron and Prabowo Subianto. In July, the French culture minister welcomed Indonesian counterparts to Paris, where they adopted a cultural roadmap with particular emphasis on cinema, Penone says.


	The France-Indonesia Film Lab, running Nov. 27 through Dec. 1 in Yogyakarta, has scaled up significantly from its inaugural 2024 edition. â€œWe are identifying emerging talents in Indonesia, and we are following them, mentoring them,â€ Penone tells Variety at the JAFF Market. â€œThis year, we have identified six Indonesian teams, producer and film directors who are in the process of developing their first or second feature film. The objective is basically to pave the way for future Indonesia-France co-productions.â€

	The lab has been reinforced with two key components. â€œFirst, cinema scriptwriting, with the support of CNC cinema agency,â€ Penone says. â€œWe are mentoring those young talents for them to get the tools to be in capacity to meet our producers to pitch.â€ The second component is an industry lab designed to help filmmakers better understand the French ecosystem, including financing options and institutional support.
	

	Looking ahead, â€œin 2026, we will organize co-production meetings not only for Indonesia, but some other Southeast Asian countries, and then they will have the opportunity to meet our producers,â€ he says.

	Five French experts are participating in this yearâ€™s lab, including Thomas Rosso, the general coordinator from Cannes Criticsâ€™ Week, and four producers already working in Southeast Asia. â€œThe lab is longer than last year, so we have much more time to accompany these young talents,â€ Penone notes.

	Beyond the lab, France is launching multiple initiatives to elevate Indonesian cinemaâ€™s international profile. The French Cinematheque will host a retrospective of Indonesian cinema beginning Dec. 10 in Paris, showcasing major Indonesian films from independence to present day and providing visibility for Indonesian cinema to French audiences and industry professionals, Penone says.

	Indonesian Culture Minister Fadli Zon will attend and meet with French Culture Minister Rachida Dati to discuss further operationalization of the July roadmap.

	In 2026, Indonesian filmmakers will gain visibility at specialized French festivals. GÃ©rardmer Film Festival will spotlight Indonesia for the first time, with filmmaker Joko Anwar as guest of honor, Penone says. The ambassador notes this creates opportunities to screen Anwarâ€™s work, describing him as among Indonesiaâ€™s most talented horror and fantasy filmmakers.

	Clermont-Ferrand International Short Film Festival will also feature Indonesian short films. â€œWe think there are many opportunities for young Indonesian filmmakers because the short movies here are very creative, very interesting. We want to showcase the dynamism of Indonesian cinema,â€ Penone says.

	Cannes Criticsâ€™ Week has announced Next Step Studio Indonesia, a short film co-creation program for emerging Indonesian directors launching in May 2026.

	The partnership emphasizes reciprocal learning. â€œThis is real partnership,â€ Penone says. â€œWe are co-financing all our programs, co-defining the objectives, and co-implementing all the initiatives. We have a lot to learn and gain from our partnership with Indonesia. We consider that both countries are creative with a lot of stories to tell, with a lot of talents. We want to merge our soft power.â€
	

	The collaboration operates on principles outlined in the Borobudur Declaration between the two presidents. France is working with Indonesiaâ€™s Ministry of Culture, Ministry of Creative Economy and regional governments including Jakarta and Central Java.

	While France and Indonesia have not formalized a co-production treaty, Penone emphasizes results over bureaucracy. â€œWe want to be very operational. You can sign many papers. What we want is concrete results, and this is the way we are working,â€ he says. The strategic framework exists through presidential declarations and ministerial roadmaps, with a clear goal to develop co-production through concrete projects rather than just agreements on paper.

	JAFF Market, Indonesiaâ€™s first large-scale film market, is emerging as a key platform. â€œWe consider JAFF Market as very strategic. The market is growing. It is beginning to be one of the most important cinema markets in Asia, and for sure, in Southeast Asia,â€ Penone says.

	The French Embassy has organized Festival Sinema Prancis in Indonesia for 26 years, with this yearâ€™s 27th edition coinciding with the Indonesia-France Film Lab at JAFF Market.â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹

schema.headline: France Deepens Indonesian Cinema Partnership Through Expanded Film Lab, Festival Initiatives: â€˜A Lot of Stories to Tellâ€™ (EXCLUSIVE)

title: â€˜Qodrat 3,â€™ â€˜Mayat Hidupâ€™ Among Magma Entertainment Slate at JAFF Market
description:
Leading Indonesian studio Magma Entertainment has confirmed â€œQodrat 3,â€ the latest instalment of their hit franchise, at the JAFF Market.

	Founded
body:
Leading Indonesian studio Magma Entertainment has confirmed â€œQodrat 3,â€ the latest instalment of their hit franchise, at the JAFF Market.

	Founded by siblings Charles and Linda Gozali, the children of pioneering Garuda Films producer, the late Hendrick Gozali, Magma was founded in 2003.Â 

	â€œQodrat 3â€ was first announced at the inaugural JAFF Market last year. 


	Producer Charles Gozali said: â€œMaking â€˜Qodrat 3â€™ isnâ€™t just responding to market demand, itâ€™s about protecting a cinematic legacy. We are approaching this with precision and care to ensure the third instalment stands on firm creative justification, from the directing vision and character evolution to the spiritual depth at the heart of the story.â€Â 
	

	Formally announcing the launch of â€œQodrat 3,â€ Magma Entertainment underscored â€œQodratâ€ as the studioâ€™s flagship IP as the cinematic universe expands. The next instalment of Ustadz Qodratâ€™s story will be slated for Indonesian theaters in 2028. Charles Gozali, as the main producer of â€œQodratâ€ series emphasized the significance of deliberate world-building in a discussion session held at Magma Entertainmentâ€™s booth.

	The company also unveiled â€œMayat Hidup,â€ billed as as a campy and colorful comedic horror explicitly inspired by iconic vampire flicks of Hong Kong cinema from the 80s and 90s. The producers promise a vibrant, dynamic tone that appeals to nostalgic cultural aesthetics that are valued throughout Asia. Its production is scheduled to start in 2026.

	The producers confirmed â€œBadut Gendongâ€ as the pivotal step in the expansion of the â€œQodratâ€ cinematic universe, which will be released across Indonesia in 2026. Featuring Marthino Lio as the leading role, the main plot navigates a fresh mystery of a haunting clown-doll entity.
	

	Unveiled earlier in the day was â€œBadut Gendong,â€ a co-production between Magma Entertainment, Legacy Pictures, Virtuelines Entertainment, VMS Studio, Caravan Studios and Malaysiaâ€™s Komet Productions, Skop Productions, Astro Shaw, plus Indiaâ€™s Applause Entertainment. Directed by Charles Gozali, the film also features Dayinta Melira, Clara Bernadeth and Derby Romero in the cast.

	â€œâ€˜Badut Gendongâ€™ is the natural evolution of the â€˜Qodratâ€™ universe. Weâ€™re not simply making a spin-off, weâ€™re building a larger, more immersive narrative architecture. We are committed to preserving the emotional depth that has always been the DNA of â€˜Qodrat,â€™â€ producer Linda Gozali said.

schema.headline: â€˜Qodrat 3,â€™ â€˜Mayat Hidupâ€™ Among Magma Entertainment Slate at JAFF Market

title: Guillermo Galoeâ€™s â€˜Sleepless Cityâ€™ Wins Best Film at Qatarâ€™s Inaugural Doha Film Festival
description: Guillermo Galoeâ€™s â€œSleepless City,â€ a hybrid drama set inside Europeâ€™s largest informal settlement, took the top narrative prize at the inaugural Do
body:
Guillermo Galoeâ€™s â€œSleepless City,â€ a hybrid drama set inside Europeâ€™s largest informal settlement, took the top narrative prize at the inaugural Doha Film Festival. The weeklong event, which closed Friday, reflected what festival director Fatma Hassan Alremaihi described as â€œa determination to champion bold voices and stories that connect audiences across borders.â€

	The film, a portrait of a marginalized Madrid community, led a slate of winners that ranged across Spain, Libya, Brazil, Palestine and Sudan, underscoring the global reach of a first edition already leaning toward politically engaged cinema.
	

	The international feature film jury, led by Oscar-nominated filmmaker Rithy Panh, joined by Raja Amari, Brigitte Lacombe, Dhafer Lâ€™Abidine and Alessandra Speciale, chose the film unanimously for the top prize, praising â€œSleepless Cityâ€ for its sensitive blend of fiction and documentary, calling it â€œa powerful portrayal of contemporary youth struggles,â€ noting its â€œrespectful directionâ€ and its ability to reflect â€œthe fracture between tradition and modernityâ€ with quiet force.


	Shot over several years in the neighborhood of La CaÃ±ada Real on the outskirts of Madrid, this yearâ€™s SACD screenwriting award winner at Cannes, follows 15-year-old Toni as looming demolitions threaten the precarious home he shares with his scrap-dealer family. Rather than constructing drama, the film observes it, letting everyday gestures accumulate into a portrait of a community rarely depicted on screen.

	Documentary Honors for a Personal Political Reckoning
	

	The documentary prize went to â€œMy Father and Qaddafi,â€ Jihan K.â€™s intimate investigation into the disappearance of her father, a Libyan diplomat-turned-dissident abducted in Cairo. The film blends testimony and archive material to piece together a life shaped by resistance, impressing the jury with its clear, personal approach to political history.

	Other Standouts in the International Feature Film Competition

	The jury also recognized several other titles across the international feature lineup. Pablo PÃ©rez Lombardiniâ€™s â€œThe Reserveâ€ received a Special Mention for its tense portrait of a forest ranger confronting environmental devastation in rural Mexico.

	The Best Performance Award was shared by Majd Eid and Nader Abd Alhay for their work in â€œOnce Upon a Time in Gaza,â€ winner of best director honors in this yearâ€™s Un Certain Regard at Cannes. Set in Gaza in 2007, the film follows a student whose side gig delivering food for a charismatic restaurateur draws him into a dangerous game with a corrupt policeman.

	Best Artistic Achievement was jointly awarded to Kamal Al Jafari for â€œWith Hasan in Gazaâ€ and Chie Hayakawa for â€œRenoir,â€ two films praised for their nuanced use of archival and visual storytelling.

	Short Film Jury Highlights Inventiveness Across Regions

	In the international short competition, presided over by head of Locarno shorts selection committee, Eddie Bertozzi, Leonardo Martinelliâ€™s â€œSamba Infinitoâ€ was cited for its â€œunflinching trust in the power of cinema and the arts to heal social and private wounds.â€ The short follows a street cleaner mourning his sisterâ€™s death whose chance encounter with a lost child during Carnival becomes a brief moment of connection.

	Other awards went to Aria SÃ¡nchez and Marina Meira, who won Best Director for â€œPrimary Education,â€ a sharp look at power and conformity among schoolchildren; Milica Janevski, named Best Performance for her turn in â€œUpon Sunriseâ€ as a Serbian mother pushed to the edge of survival; and to â€œLâ€™Minaâ€ and young actor Ammar Ahmed in â€œZizou,â€ both receiving Special Mentions.

	Youth Jury Makes a Stark Political Statement With â€˜The Voice of Hind Rajabâ€™

	One of the festivalâ€™s most talked-about titles, â€œThe Voice of Hind Rajab,â€ the opening feature, took the Ajyal Feature Award, chosen by a youth jury aged 16 to 25. The film reconstructs the final phone call of a six-year-old girl trapped under fire in Gaza, blending real recorded audio with staged reenactments. Its simplicity gives the recorded voices a force thatâ€™s hard to shake.
	

	The Ajyal Short Award went to â€œSulaimani,â€ Vinnie Ann Boseâ€™s Paris-set animated film about two young women from Kerala whose chance encounter in Paris is an exploration of diaspora, memory, and identity through the language of food.

	Local Filmmaking Comes Into Focus in â€˜Made in Qatarâ€™ Awards

	The festivalâ€™s commitment to nurturing homegrown talent came through in the Made in Qatar competition, where Justin Kramerâ€™s â€œFahad the Furiousâ€ won Best Film. The short from the Qatar-based American director, part family drama, part comedic character study, follows a young man whose secrecy sets off a chain of misunderstandings inside his traditional home. Rashid Al Sheeb earned the Abdulaziz Jassim Award for Performance for his leading role in the film.

	Eiman Mirghani won Best Director for â€œVilla 187,â€ a story of memory and loss set within a family forced to leave the Doha home that defined them for decades. â€œProject Aisha,â€ a tense drama about a mother whose unorthodox attempts to care for her injured daughter push her family to the breaking point, received a Special Mention from the Made in Qatar jury.

	Audience Award for â€˜Cotton Queen,â€™ a Story of Heritage and Transformation

	Festivalgoers voted â€œCotton Queenâ€ as the Audience Award winner, marking a strong international showing for Sudanese filmmaker Suzannah Mirghani. Expanding the world of her award-winning short â€œAl-Sit,â€ the feature follows teenage Nafisa as her Sudanese village faces pressure to modernize, and as she herself becomes the focal point of competing visions for the future. Shot after the outbreak of war in Sudan, with Sudanese refugees recreating the village in Egypt, the productionâ€™s circumstances echoed the filmâ€™s themes of resilience and displacement.

	A Debut Edition with a Clear Sense of Direction

	With 97 films from 62 countries, the inaugural edition laid out a broad mandate, mixing personal dramas, inventive shorts, and politically grounded documentaries with a growing slate of local work. The industry activity around the festival signaled Qatarâ€™s ambitions, but the programming itself did some heavy lifting in its own right. Doha introduced itself as a place that wants to attract international filmmakers while building its own creative base, a dual focus reflected in a set of winners that felt urgent, assured, and cohesive.

schema.headline: Guillermo Galoeâ€™s â€˜Sleepless Cityâ€™ Wins Best Film at Qatarâ€™s Inaugural Doha Film Festival

title: Indonesia-Malaysia Co-Productions Surge With Four New Film Projects at JAFF Market
description: A quartet of Indonesian-Malaysian film co-productions was unveiled at the JAFF Market, signaling an uptick in collaboration between the two Southeas
body:
A quartet of Indonesian-Malaysian film co-productions was unveiled at the JAFF Market, signaling an uptick in collaboration between the two Southeast Asian territories.

	The projects â€” â€œMunafik,â€ â€œKhurafat,â€ â€œKhadamâ€ and â€œBadut Gendongâ€ â€” were announced during a session titled â€œThe Nusantara Wave: The Rise of Indonesia-Malaysia Collaborationsâ€ at the eventâ€™s Plaza Center Stage. The JAFF Market runs in conjunction with the Jogja-Netpac Asia Film Festival.
	

	â€œMunafik,â€ an Indonesian adaptation of Malaysiaâ€™s top-grossing horror franchise, has completed principal photography and entered post-production. Helmed by Guntur Soeharjanto and starring Arya Saloka and Acha Septriasa, the project screened a first-look teaser at the event. The production is led by Oswin Bonifanz of Unlimited Productions, with Malaysiaâ€™s Skop Productions, Komet Productions and Indonesiaâ€™s A&Z Films and Legacy Pictures also producing.


	Building on that momentum, an Indonesian version of Malaysian horror-religious film â€œKhurafatâ€ was also revealed, with Zahir Omar attached to direct. The original, directed by Syamsul Yusof, broke Malaysian box office records. Skop Productions indicated that Indonesian co-producers for the remake will be announced soon.

	â€œOur increasing collaboration with Indonesiaâ€™s leading producers and creatives reflects our commitment to working with the very best talent in the region,â€ said Shamin Yusof, CEO of Skop Productions. â€œBy entrusting two of our biggest franchises, â€˜Munafikâ€™ and â€˜Khurafat,â€™ to be reimagined as marquee Indonesian films by top-tier Indonesian filmmakers, we are making a bold statement.â€
	

	The event also presented a first look at â€œKhadam,â€ a horror-drama currently in post-production featuring Indonesian actor Aghniny Haque and Malaysian star Remy Ishak. Directed by Shamyl Othman, the film is produced by Malaysiaâ€™s Komet Productions and Red Communications, Chinaâ€™s Sil-Metropole and Indiaâ€™s Applause Entertainment. A signing ceremony welcomed Indonesiaâ€™s Magma Entertainment as executive producer.

	â€œThis event is the perfect opportunity to describe what we call the new Nusantara wave, where we can see a marked increase in creative collaboration between our two countries,â€ said Ahmad Izham Omar, chief explorer of Komet Productions. â€œThere is so much potential for new levels of synergy and quality when we combine talents, ideas and skills from Indonesia and Malaysia.â€

	The session concluded with a first look at â€œBadut Gendong,â€ a co-production between Magma Entertainment, Legacy Pictures, Virtuelines Entertainment, VMS Studio, Caravan Studios and Malaysiaâ€™s Komet Productions, Skop Productions, Astro Shaw, plus Indiaâ€™s Applause Entertainment. Directed by Charles Gozali, the film features Marthino Lio, Dayinta Melira, Clara Bernadeth and Derby Romero.

	â€œWhen different cultures, backgrounds and skillsets come together to create, we will never ever be able to predict the magic that will happen,â€ said Linda Gozali, CEO of Magma Entertainment. â€œMagma has a long history of working with Malaysian creatives.â€

	Datoâ€™ Azmir Mutalib, CEO of Malaysiaâ€™s National Film Development Corporation (FINAS), added, â€œThis is a very positive development of co-production efforts between Indonesia and Malaysia. FINAS will always support these types of efforts to increase awareness of the great stories coming out of this region for the world to enjoy.â€

	The session was also attended by actor Izabel Jahja (who appears in the â€œMunafikâ€ remake) and Charles Gozali, director of the â€œQodratâ€ franchise.

schema.headline: Indonesia-Malaysia Co-Productions Surge With Four New Film Projects at JAFF Market

title: Kim Kardashian's New Scan Shows Low Brain Activity, Studying Stress To Blame
description:
Kim Kardashian
                          Low Brain Activity on Scan...
body:
Kim Kardashian
                          Low Brain Activity on Scan...
                          Studying Stress to Blame!!!
                      
                  
                        Published November 28, 2025 3:51 PM PST
                                                                      |
                Updated November 28, 2025 4:44 PM PST
                                    
      
    
      
        
                    
                  
      
                    Hulu
          
    
          Kim Kardashian just got one hell of a wake-up call -- her latest scan showed low brain activity, and the doc says itâ€™s all likely triggered by the massive studying stress sheâ€™s been grinding through.
      
    
          On Thursdayâ€™s episode of "The Kardashians," Kim sat down to look over her scans with Dr. Amen -- fresh off her brain aneurysm diagnosis -- and he pointed out the "holes" in her brain scan, saying theyâ€™re basically what chronic stress looks like.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Dr. Amen explained the low activity meant the front part of her brain wasnâ€™t firing the way it should -- not exactly ideal considering Kim was deep in study mode and getting ready to take her boards at the time of filming.
      

                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Kim was devastated -- totally not accepting the results at first -- but the doc told her it could all be tied to the insane stress sheâ€™s under while studying for the California bar, and even gave her tips on how to manage it.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Good thing he did, â€™cause as we all know, Kim failed the bar... so the stress (and the studying) is far from over!

schema.headline: Kim Kardashian's New Scan Shows Low Brain Activity, Studying Stress To Blame

          Looks like all that post-divorce refresh paid off -- Porsha Williams just hard-launched her new girlfriend, and sis is glowing like she hit the jackpot!
      
    
          In IG pics shared Friday -- snapped in front of her Christmas tree -- Porshaâ€™s getting cradled from behind by her new GF, Sway The Pro (real name Patrice McKinney) ... and the two look seriously smitten.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Porsha was radiating happiness while wishing her new boo a happy birthday -- rocking a leopard-print dress and looking all kinds of stunning as she cozied up with Sway ... who popped up in more pics from the carousel, including one where sheâ€™s planting a sweet kiss on Porshaâ€™s cheek.
      

                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          The 'Real Housewives of Atlanta' star has def moved on from ex-hubby Simon Guobadia -- and it looks like Patrice is the one who stole the top spot ... especially after Porsha said last month sheâ€™d been talking to two people: a man and a woman.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Speaking at CultureCon, she said they were both nice, normal people -- not narcissists -- which actually made it harder for her to open up, since her old patterns had her going all-in with love-bombing narcs in the past.
      
    
          Weâ€™re loving this new romance, girl ... go live your best hard-launch life, Porsha!
